description:
Lacticaseibacillus paracasei is a species of Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, and rod-shaped bacteria. It belongs to the Lacticaseibacillus genus, which is part of the Lactobacillaceae family within the Firmicutes phylum.

L. paracasei is a lactic acid-producing bacterium, meaning it can convert carbohydrates, such as lactose, into lactic acid as a byproduct of its metabolism. This species is commonly found in dairy products, such as cheese and yogurt, where it plays a role in the fermentation process.

L. paracasei is known for its probiotic properties, as it can provide beneficial effects on the human gastrointestinal system when consumed. It has been studied for its potential to improve digestive health, enhance immune function, and support overall well-being.

The genome of L. paracasei has been sequenced, revealing insights into its metabolic capabilities, stress response mechanisms, and ability to adapt to various environmental conditions. This information has helped researchers understand the role of this species in food production and its potential as a probiotic supplement.
